qas.question: What has been widely debated as a possible act of genocide in Sudan?
In 2003 what well known U.S. Secretary of State declared the situation in Darfur as an act of genocide?
In front of which committee did Powell testify?
What did UN Security Council Resolution 1564 authorize in 2004?

answers.text: an International Commission of Inquiry on Darfur

qas.question: Despite some concessions, what act did the Commission ultimately state that Sudan had not pursued?
What has been widely debated as a possible act of genocide in the UN?
In 2003 what well known U.S. Secretary of State declared the situation in the UN as an act of genocide?
In front of which committee did Darfur testify?

plausible_answers.text: an International Commission of Inquiry on Darfur

qas.question: What did UN Security Council Resolution 1564 authorize in 2005?
Despite some concessions, what act did the Commission ultimately state that the UN had not pursued?

context: There has been much debate over categorizing the <a0_0><b5_0>situation in Darfur<b5_0/><a0_0/> as genocide. The ongoing conflict in Darfur, Sudan, which started in 2003, was declared a "genocide" by United States Secretary of State <a1_0><b6_0>Colin Powell<b6_0/><a1_0/> on 9 September 2004 in testimony before <a2_0>the <b7_0>Senate Foreign Relations Committee<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Since that time however, no other permanent member of the UN Security Council followed suit. In fact, in January 2005, <a3_0><b8_0>an International Commission of Inquiry on Darfur<b8_0/><a3_0/>, authorized by UN Security Council Resolution 1564 of 2004, issued a report to the Secretary-General stating that "the Government of the Sudan has not pursued a policy of genocide." Nevertheless, the Commission cautioned that "The conclusion that no <a4_0><b9_0>genocidal policy<b9_0/><a4_0/> has been pursued and implemented in Darfur by the Government authorities, directly or through the militias under their control, should not be taken in any way as detracting from the gravity of the crimes perpetrated in that region. International offences such as the crimes against humanity and war crimes that have been committed in Darfur may be no less serious and heinous than genocide."
